Line 47: Line 47:
{{main|List of Google services and tools}}
{{main|List of Google services and tools}}
Google's core business is to provide a free internet search engine with advertisements placed along side and above the "natural" search listings. As of 2005, Google's [[AdWords]] advertising program generated nearly all of Google's income.[http://news.com.com/Google+revenue+nearly+doubles/2100-1030_3-5905127.html] Google also distributes ads to search partner companies, and a large number of content network web sites participating in the Google [[AdSense]] program.
Google's core business is to provide a free internet search engine with advertisements placed along side and above the "natural" search listings. As of 2005, Google's [[AdWords]] advertising program generated nearly all of Google's income.[http://news.com.com/Google+revenue+nearly+doubles/2100-1030_3-5905127.html] Google also distributes ads to search partner companies, and a large number of content network web sites participating in the Google [[AdSense]] program.
  +   +
[[dodgeball.com]] is a new social networking site built specifically for mobile phones. purchased by google in 2005.
[[Froogle]] is Google's shopping search engine that is geared towards searching online shopping websites for products based on price. [[List of Google services and tools#Groups|Google Groups]] is a service that lets users search the complete archive of [[Usenet]] newsgroups, as well as hosting mailing lists and other discussion groups. In early [[2006]], the company also launched [[Google Video]], which not only allows users to search and view freely available videos, but also offers various media publishers to offer their content for a fee, including television shows on [[CBS]], [[NBA]] basketball games, and music videos. Videos offered via this service are protected using Google's own [[Digital rights management]] system.

In early [[2006]], the company also launched [[Google Video]], which not only allows users to search and view freely available videos, but also offers various media publishers to offer their content for a fee, including television shows on [[CBS]], [[NBA]] basketball games, and music videos. Videos offered via this service are protected using Google's own [[Digital rights management]] system.
